p: In the past, there have been re-evaluations of how international relations are to be conducted in the aftermath of major economic disruptions. In the aftermath of the First World War, for example, the economic arm of the League of Nations produced a significant degree of international cooperation, resulting in the 1927 World Economic Conference, which also included non-members, viz., the USA. The countries involved in the conference decided that it was time to terminate tariffs (League of Nations, 1927). However, with the passage of the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act in the USA in June 1930, countries switched from relatively free international trading systems to a high degree of protectionism in the wake of the economic fallout from 1929 stock market crash. Canada was the first nation to retaliate in May 1930, long before Smoot-Hawley was signed into law [45]. Many other nations followed suit, raising tariffs and trade barriers against each other and the USA.
